content:
UK/EU

BoE said its reasonable for financial services firms to plan on being able to continue undertaking activities during Brexit implementation period much as they do now and that in the unlikely event that EU withdrawal deal is not ratified, a back-stop for authorisation or recognition will provide confidence. (Newswires)

FX

The DXY closed green for the second day rising above 90.00, now eyeing the 90.50 level which marks the top-end of its recent range. The buck is said to be supported by month-end rebalancing along with a more constructive tone regarding Trade Wars, many are attributing the USD strength to an unwind of the premium within safe haven FX, with USDJPY flirting with 107.00 in Wednesday trade (the north Korea headlines helped buoy the pair), while gold slides towards $1320. Month-end models also see EUR selling, and the single currency gradually slid against the USD through the course of US trading, coming back to test the 1.23 level, which has been cited as key support. In quiet trade, GBPUSD mirrored EURUSD action, sliding by around 0.5% to the ~1.41 level, trading slightly below the figure as we head into Asia. The oil slide/risk-off tone did nothing to help AUD or NZD; the former has backed-off 0.77 towards 0.7650, while the latter has found support above 0.72. EMFX was a function of USD strength, though positive NAFTA landscape (the focus in Trade Wars has shifted to China) has helped the peso.

MARKET RECAP

Tuesday's tech sell-off spread into Asia, which then spread into European trade, though S&P 500 eminis were horizontal overnight and through the European morning. The cash contract was meandering around the neutral line for most of US trade. Defensives were better performers amid a generally soft risk tone. Most FAANG saw another day of selling (though Alphabet and FB fared well). In stock specifics, a number of brokerages cut their estimates for AAPL iPhone production in Q2 citing soft demand for high-end smartphones. For CVS and AET, an FDA official expressed concerns about consolidation within the pharmacy benefit management sector. In M&A, CACI withdrew its offer to buy CSRA (GD also recently made an offer). And in earnings, WBA beat on the top and bottom lines. SPX -0.31% at 2605, DJI -0.04% at 23848, NDX -1.06% at 6460.

Yields started out the day lower on risk-aversion, while portfolio re-balancing was also being cited ahead of month-end (extensions are said to be supportive this month). Naturally, there was focus on 10-year yields, after they moved below the 200dma. At settlement, the curve was mixed; there was more clarity in curve spreads, however, with 2s10s c.2bps flatter, 2s30s c.4bps flatter (to the narrowest since 2007), 5s10s 2bps flatter, and 5s30s 4bps flatter. 2s5s was relatively unchanged. This week's bumper supply out of the US Treasury was capped by a weak 7-year auction, which tailed by 1.9bps, with cover softer than recent averages. Other internals were also weak, with dealer take down rising to 32% (12 ppts higher than recent averages), while indirect participation was the lowest since Feb 2016. Yields ticked higher after the auction, moving into negative territory. US T-Note Futures (Jun) unchanged at 120-29.

US MARKET WRAP: Markets mixed ahead of month/qtr-end
content:
US MARKET WRAP: Markets mixed ahead of month/qtr-end

* SNAPSHOT: Stocks down, treasuries up; crude down, dollar up.
* REAR-VIEW: US Q4 GDP revised up, DOE data shows smaller build than API, SARB cuts.
* AHEAD: US PCE (Thurs), German inflation (Thurs), Canada GDP (Thurs), Fed's Harker (Thurs).

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.31% at 2605, DJI -0.04% at 23848, NDX -1.06% at 6460. Sectors: Telecoms +1.7%, Non-cyclicals +1.5%, Health +0.6%, Financials +0.4%, Utilities -0.2%, Industrials -0.5%, Tech -0.6%, Cyclicals -1.2%, Materials -1.3%, Energy -1.9%.

* Tuesday's tech sell-off spread into Asia, which then spread into European trade, though S&P 500 eminis were horizontal overnight and through the European morning. The cash contract was meandering around the neutral line for most of US trade. Defensives were better performers amid a generally soft risk tone. Most FAANG saw another day of selling (though Alphabet and FB fared well). In stock specifics, a number of brokerages cut their estimates for AAPL iPhone production in Q2 citing soft demand for high-end smartphones. For CVS and AET, an FDA official expressed concerns about consolidation within the pharmacy benefit management sector. In M&A, CACI withdrew its offer to buy CSRA (GD also recently made an offer). And in earnings, WBA beat on the top and bottom lines.

* TREASURIES: US T-Note Futures (Jun) unchanged at 120-29. Yields started out the day lower on risk-aversion, while portfolio re-balancing was also being cited ahead of month-end (extensions are said to be supportive this month). Naturally, there was focus on 10-year yields, after they moved below the 200dma. At settlement, the curve was mixed; there was more clarity in curve spreads, however, with 2s10s c.2bps flatter, 2s30s c.4bps flatter (to the narrowest since 2007), 5s10s 2bps flatter, and 5s30s 4bps flatter. 2s5s was relatively unchanged. This week's bumper supply out of the US Treasury was capped by a weak 7-year auction, which tailed by 1.9bps, with cover softer than recent averages. Other internals were also weak, with dealer take down rising to 32% (12 ppts higher than recent averages), while indirect participation was the lowest since Feb 2016. Yields ticked higher after the auction, moving into negative territory. 

* FOREX: DXY +0.8% heading into APAC trade. The DXY closes green for the second day, rising above 90.00, now eyeing the 90.50 level which marks the top-end of its recent range. The buck is said to be supported by month-end rebalancing. along with a more constructive tone regarding Trade Wars, many are attributing the USD strength to an unwind of the premium within safe haven FX, with USDJPY flirting with 107.00 in Wednesday trade (the north Korea headlines helped buoy the pair), while gold slides towards $1320. Month-end models also see EUR selling, and the single currency gradually slid against the USD through the course of US trading, coming back to test the 1.23 level, which has been cited as key support. In quiet trade, GBPUSD mirrored EURUSD action, sliding by around 0.5% to the ~1.41 level, trading slightly below the figure as we head into Asia. The oil slide/risk-off tone did nothing to help AUD or NZD; the former has backed-off 0.77 towards 0.7650, while the latter has found support above 0.72. EMFX was a function of USD strength, though positive NAFTA landscape (the focus in Trade Wars has shifted to China) has helped the peso. 

* CRUDE: WTI futures for May settle 87 cents lower at $64.38/bbl; Brent settles 58 cents lower at $69.53/bbl. WTI red for the third straight session, with inventory data and USD strength weighing on the complex. DOE energy inventory data showed headline crude stocks building more moderately than was suggested by API data on Tuesday, helping crude prices to stage a small rally. However, that rally proved fleeting, and as the dust settled, prices came back within the day’s range, before continuing the drift lower beneath $64, before gradually making its way back above the figure. Crude looked-through another dose of OPEC jawboning; on Tuesday, Iraq’s oil minister said that some crude exporters would like to extend the supply cut agreement for another six months (when it expires at the end of the year), while OPEC’s Sec Gen Barkindo said oil industry investments are on an upswing, though is yet to reach pre-crisis levels. Crude traders have been taking their cues from geopolitical developments in recent trade, rather than fundamentals/OPEC jawbone; today EU envoys said Iranian sanctions is being sought at the next foreign minister’s meeting on 16/April (recall, US President Trump has until 12/May to make a decision on whether to reapply sanctions on Iran)

 * GEOPOLITICS: North Korea continues to signal a dovish approach to peace negotiations through conciliatory actions. After it was confirmed that it held talks with China over the weekend, today Japanese press reported the nation was looking to hold a summit with Japan.

* US Q4 GDP: The third reading of Q4 GDP data saw upward revisions to the headline (2.9% vs 2.7% exp) putting 2017 growth at 2.6%. Q4 growth was buoyed by consumer sector (Strongest showing in three years) and less drag from inventories. Analysts noted that the conditions are in place for continued growth in 2018 (tax cuts and fiscal expenditure), which should keep the Fed on course to tighten policy through the year.

subject: AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 29bln of 7-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: Ex-bills, the US Treasury will sell USD 109bln this week in 2-year (USD 30bln, Monday), 5-year notes (USD 35bln, Tuesday), 7-year (USD 29bln, Wednesday), as well as a 2-year FRN (USD 15bln, Wednesday). With USD 66.3bln maturing at end-month settlement, net supply is implied at USD 42.7bln, according to TD Securities.

7-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The January auction of 7-year notes was poor, tailing by 0.7bps versus the 1pm when issued yield, while the auction saw the softest cover since November. In terms of positioning, SocGen has noted that dealers are long in the 6 to 7-year bucket to the tune of USD 5.7bln, the highest in five weeks. SocGen argues that the current 7-year trades cheap on asset swap versus off-the-runs, though trades rich on the fly versus 5s and 10s. The bank therefore has a negative bias heading into the 7-year auction. The bank notes that month-end extension may provide support for the auction.

Daily FX Wrap: Buck remains flavour of the month, quarter and fy end, Chf and Jpy unloved
content: Aside from a few interruptions and minor corrections, the overriding trend has been more Dollar buying for end of March, Q1 and Japanese fiscal year end portfolio rebalancing purposes. Indeed, with only one full trading session left of the current month the Greenback has extended gains vs all G10 counterparts plus other majors and EM currencies. The DXY has subsequently staged a firmer bounce from recent sub-89.000 lows to within striking distance of the 90.000 level again, and could continue its revival on any residual/last minute demand ahead of the long Easter weekend. The ‘safe-havens’ are underperforming as ongoing global trade/protectionism tensions appear to be less pronounced vs latest signs of progress on the geopolitical front via NK-SK-US nuclear talks. Usd/Chf is up around 0.9550 again and Eur/Chf not far off 1.1800+ year-to-date peaks (in fact, highest since the SNB peg was removed back in January 2015) amidst more Swiss CB commentary about the highly valued Franc and dovish monetary policy rhetoric. Usd/Jpy eclipsed its 200 HMA and a key Fib on the way through 106.00-20 offers, with the Jpy also undermined by selling interest from domestic importers and potential M&A related flows (due to Takeda’s designs on Shire). Eur/Usd tried to hang around 1.2400, but caved and breached its 100 HMA and is now testing support in the 1.2339-35 area, which includes the 30 DMA. Cable looks to have topped out again circa 1.4200 and eventually took out macro offers between 1.4135-25 to lose grip of the 1.4000 handle, while the commodity bloc also lost more ground vs the Usd – Aud testing 0.7750 and a fib, Nzd under 0.7250 and a decent option expiry at the strike and Cad testing the psychological 1.2900 level again.

content: Not much net reaction to the deluge of US releases, but bonds remain off best levels on the better than expected elements and the Dollar retains a bid as stocks sit just below their recovery highs. In contrast, the Jpy continues to underperform across the board on multiple negative factors and sheer bearish momentum, with Usd/Jpy through 106.00, 106.20 offers and recent peaks at 106.30 or thereabouts, and Gbp/jpy over the 150.00 mark again. DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European equities have extended losses after tech slipped on Wall St. and Asia
content:
• European equities have extended losses after tech slipped on Wall St. and Asia
  • USD firmer vs. all G10 approaching quarter and Japanese financial year end
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US GDP, PCE Prices, Pending Home Sales, DoEs and Fed’s Bostic

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the losses on Wall St where trade concerns lingered and tech sold-off, while some also attributed the exacerbated pressure to flows heading into month-end and Easter break. As such, ASX 200 (-0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) were lower as tech stocks conformed to the losses in their counterparts stateside, while weakness in commodities also contributed to the glum. Elsewhere, KOSPI (-1.3%) pharmaceutical and metal stocks joined the tech underperformance after reports stated South Korea steel exports to US would decline 30% under the new trade agreement and that South Korea will amend its premium pricing program for pharmaceuticals to allow participation of US drug makers. Hang Seng (-2.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.4%) were also dragged by the tech slide, while encouraging earnings from big 4 banks ICBC and China Construction Bank only provided brief support and was eventually engulfed by the stock rout. Finally, 10yr JGBs saw a tale of two-halves as they initially tracked the gains in T-notes amid a flight to quality from the stock market sell-off and with the BoJ also present in the market under its bond buying program, before gains were then pared on return from the Tokyo break in which prices returned flat.

PBoC skipped open market operations again today for a net drain of CNY 10bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2785 (Prev. 6.2816)

CENTRAL BANKS

BoJ Governor Kuroda reiterates to continue pursuing powerful easing and says commitment is vital to increase policy impact. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

UK is said to inform Irish officials that a resolution to the hard border issue is imminent, according to sources. (Times)

EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx -1.0%) have extended on the risk-averse tone seen in the US and Asia, triggered by a tech sell-off which prompted losses within the IT sector in Europe this morning, augmented by month-end flows. As such, semiconductors are the laggards with Dialog Semiconductors (-13.0%), Infineon (-4.0%), ASML Holding (-4.4%) and STMicroelectronics (-5.2%) the worst performers whereas utilities remain slightly supported. In terms of individual movers, Shire (+15.5%) is leading the FTSE 100 and lifting the healthcare sector (+0.5%) after Takeda confirmed to be considering an offer for the Co., although considerations are at a prelim stage and no approach has been made yet. Elsewhere, Melrose (-0.5%) have continued to defend their approach for GKN ahead of tomorrow’s deadline.

FX

Another rebalancing model is Usd positive for month, quarter and Japanese financial year end, albeit ‘moderately’, while a separate bank is looking to buy the Greenback vs the Pound, Loonie, Aud and Nok if global stocks fall further. Hence, the Dollar retains an underlying bid on dips and is firmer vs all G10 peers bar the Gbp, which is deriving some independent support on latest Brexit headlines (reports that an Irish border resolution is in the offing). Cable and Eur/Gbp are bucking the broader trend, with the former hovering just below 1.4200 after a retreat to test the first layer of bids said to be macro-related in the 1.4135-25 area, and the latter seeing some resistance around 0.8750. Eur/Usd is also holding up relatively well near 1.2400 where decent option expiry interest lies (1.6 bn), but also as tech support at the 100 HMA (1.2379) holds. In fact, the Eur is defying some end of March ‘strong’ selling calls and outperforming other majors, like the Sek and Nok in wake of weaker than expected retail sales data from both Scandi nations overall. Even the Chf is weaker despite the resurgence of risk aversion, while its traditional safe-haven counterpart, Jpy, is caught between the aforementioned downturn in sentiment and more positive geopolitical vibes on the NK-SK-US front. Usd/Jpy rangy between 105.69 and 105.96 200 HMA and Fib levels respectively. Usd/Cad is back around 1.2900 despite constructive NAFTA negotiations, while Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd remain bearish, as the former has breached its recent 0.7672 low and the latter tests support/bids at 0.7250.

FIXED INCOME

The 10-year EU benchmarks have received another fillip as bearish pre-equity open indications come to fruition, and Bunds have now extended gains through initial tech resistance and yesterday’s 159.42 Eurex intraday apex, at 159.69 (+46 ticks), with 159.62 next on the radar. Similarly, Gilts resumed Liffe on the front foot and have already surpassed the Jun18 contract peak set last Thursday (122.26) at 122.69 (+55 ticks vs +10 ticks at the early low) and the upside objective from here is 123.00, as 122.65 represented a continuation chart high. US Treasuries tagging along and now more firmly back in bull-flattening mode, as asset correlations/positioning take on traditional FTQ characteristics.

COMMODITIES

The commodities complex continues to be subdued amid the dampened risk appetite. WTI (-0.9%) and Brent (-0.6%) futures are extending losses with prices pressured by the surprise build in API crude inventories (5.321M vs. Exp. -0.300M). Additionally, the Iraqi oil Minister Luaibi stated that Iraq will not deviate from any OPEC decisions on crude supply; this follows the Saudi Crown Prince stating OPEC seeks a 10 to 20-year supply co-operation with Russia as well as other producers. Gold (-0.1%) slipped from a 5-week high as a firmer dollar is weighing on the yellow metal. Fears of a trade war continue to cast a shadow over the base metal market with copper (-0.6%) lower and Dalian iron ore futures slipping to their lowest since June shortly after the open.

US API weekly crude stocks (23 Mar) 5.321M vs. Exp. -0.300M (Prev. -2.739M). (Newswires)

Iraq says it is not difficult to boost oil output capacity to 12mln bpd. (Newswires)

Some oil exporting nations have proposed a 6-month supply cut extension, according to the Iraqi oil minister. (Newswires)

Phillips 66 reported a unit upset at the Wood River refinery. (Newswires) This refinery has a crude capacity of 314k bpd.

GEOPOLITICAL

Reports confirmed that North Korean Leader Kim met with Chinese President Xi in which they exchanged views on improving ties and the situation in Korean peninsula, while North Korea Leader Kim was also said to be committed to denuclearization of Korean peninsula. (Xinhua)

Saudi Foreign Minister said ballistic missiles were launched by Iranian and Hezbollah agents and that Saudi has evidence of Iran arming Houthis with ballistic missiles. Furthermore, the Saudi Foreign Minister stated that the kingdom reserves the right to respond at appropriate time, while there were also separate Saudi Arabia and UN inked agreement to support Yemen. (Newswires

In fact, the Eur is defying some end of March ‘strong’ selling calls and outperforming other majors, like the Sek and Nok in wake of weaker than expected retail sales data from both Scandi nations overall. Even the Chf is weaker despite the resurgence of risk aversion, while its traditional safe-haven counterpart, Jpy, is caught between the aforementioned downturn in sentiment and more positive geopolitical vibes on the NK-SK-US front. Usd/Jpy rangy between 105.69 and 105.96 200 HMA and Fib levels respectively. Usd/Cad is back around 1.2900 despite constructive NAFTA negotiations, while Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd remain bearish, as the former has breached its recent 0.7672 low and the latter tests support/bids at 0.7250.

The 10-year EU benchmarks have received another fillip as bearish pre-equity open indications come to fruition, and Bunds have now extended gains through initial tech resistance and yesterday’s 159.42 Eurex intraday apex, at 159.69 (+46 ticks), with 159.62 next on the radar. Similarly, Gilts resumed Liffe on the front foot and have already surpassed the Jun18 contract peak set last Thursday (122.26) at 122.69 (+55 ticks vs +10 ticks at the early low) and the upside objective from here is 123.00, as 122.65 represented a continuation chart high. US Treasuries tagging along and now more firmly back in bull-flattening mode, as asset correlations/positioning take on traditional FTQ characteristics.

The commodities complex continues to be subdued amid the dampened risk appetite. WTI (-0.9%) and Brent (-0.6%) futures are extending losses with prices pressured by the surprise build in API crude inventories (5.321M vs. Exp. -0.300M). Additionally, the Iraqi oil Minister Luaibi stated that Iraq will not deviate from any OPEC decisions on crude supply; this follows the Saudi Crown Prince stating OPEC seeks a 10 to 20-year supply co-operation with Russia as well as other producers. Gold (-0.1%) slipped from a 5-week high as a firmer dollar is weighing on the yellow metal. Fears of a trade war continue to cast a shadow over the base metal market with copper (-0.6%) lower and Dalian iron ore futures slipping to their lowest since June shortly after the open.

subject: FX Morning Colour: more Dollar buying as March draws to a close
content: Another rebalancing model is Usd positive for month, quarter and Japanese financial year end, albeit ‘moderately’, while a separate bank is looking to buy the Greenback vs the Pound, Loonie, Aud and Nok if global stocks fall further. Hence, the Dollar retains an underlying bid on dips and is firmer vs all G10 peers bar the Gbp, which is deriving some independent support on latest Brexit headlines (reports that an Irish border resolution is in the offing). Cable and Eur/Gbp are bucking the broader trend, with the former hovering just below 1.4200 after a retreat to test the first layer of bids said to be macro-related in the 1.4135-25 area, and the latter seeing some resistance around 0.8750. Eur/Usd is also holding up relatively well near 1.2400 where decent option expiry interest lies (1.6 bn), but also as tech support at the 100 HMA (1.2379) holds. In fact, the Eur is defying some end of March ‘strong’ selling calls and outperforming other majors, like the Sek and Nok in wake of weaker than expected retail sales data from both Scandi nations overall. Even the Chf is weaker despite the resurgence of risk aversion, while its traditional safe-haven counterpart, Jpy, is caught between the aforementioned downturn in sentiment and more positive geopolitical vibes on the NK-SK-US front. Usd/Jpy rangy between 105.69 and 105.96 200 HMA and Fib levels respectively. Usd/Cad is back around 1.2900 despite constructive NAFTA negotiations, while Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd remain bearish, as the former has breached its recent 0.7672 low and the latter tests support/bids at 0.7250.

subject: Daily G7 Bond Auction Preview
content:
AUCTION PREVIEW: ECB 3-Month LTRO allotment

Previously, the ECB allotted EUR 2.81bln in its 3-month LTRO

AUCTION PREVIEW: Italian EUR 4.5-5.5bln 0.95% 2023 and 2.0% 2028 BTP, EUR 1.5-2bln 2025 CCTeu

Barclays: 

BTP Mar 23 trades just under 11bp cheap in ASW terms vs. the last 5y benchmark bond, a valuation that is on the cheap side compared with recent rolls. Cross market, Italy has widened 4.5bp vs. Spain this week and by just over 8bp vs Portugal, leaving spreads at 6m wides vs. Spain and multi-year wides vs. Portugal.

BTP Feb 28 trades at a benchmark discount of just under 4.5bp here which looks around fair value. Cross market cheapening thus far in March against Spain has been c.14bp and 15bp vs. Portugal as election concerns have weighed on Italy. This has taken spreads in the 5y area back to 6m wides vs. Spain and multi-year wides vs. Portugal.

In terms of historical data:

0.95% 2023 has no directly comparable data

2.0% 2028 prev. b/c 1.25 and average yield 2.06%

2025 CTZ prev. b/c 1.63 and average yield 0.42%

Bids are submitted by 1030BST and results are published shortly after  

 

US to sell USD 29bln of 7-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT

THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: Ex-bills, the US Treasury will sell USD 109bln this week in 2-year (USD 30bln, Monday), 5-year notes (USD 35bln, Tuesday), 7-year (USD 29bln, Wednesday), as well as a 2-year FRN (USD 15bln, Wednesday). With USD 66.3bln maturing at end-month settlement, net supply is implied at USD 42.7bln, according to TD Securities.

7-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The January auction of 7-year notes was poor, tailing by 0.7bps versus the 1pm when issued yield, while the auction saw the softest cover since November. In terms of positioning, SocGen has noted that dealers are long in the 6 to 7-year bucket to the tune of $5.7bln, the highest in five weeks. SocGen argues that the current 7-year trades cheap on asset swap versus off-the-runs, though trades rich on the fly versus 5s and 10s. The bank therefore has a negative bias heading into the 7-year auction. The bank notes that month-end extension may provide support for the auction.

subject: Bunds: extending gains above 159.00, 10 year yield testing 0.5% bids/support
content: A gap up and fleeting dip before grinding higher off the Eurex open, as the 10 year German benchmark tests near term chart resistance in the 159.25-32 area, but encounters some cash-related offers as the corresponding benchmark yield trades around the psychological 0.5% level, last breached back in January. In terms of futures, a clean break up and out of the early 159.24-34 range exposes a bullish rising channel objective and another symbolic marker at 159.50, but further gains are likely to hinge on how (badly) EU bourses react to the latest meltdown on Wall Street and knock-on losses in Asia-Pac equities overnight. Month, Q1 and Japan’s fiscal year end will also continue to impact on trade/direction, while markets weigh the implications/repercussions of ongoing trade wars and geopolitical developments. Ahead, not a lot in the way of regional data, but more Italian supply to digest before the last UST auctions of the week and several top-tier US releases including the Fed’s preferred inflation metric – core PCE.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from GSK, GKN/Melrose, and Deutsche Bank
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

28th March 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the losses on Wall St where trade concerns lingered and tech sold-off, while some also attributed the exacerbated pressure to flows heading into month-end and Easter break. As such, ASX 200 (-0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) were lower as tech stocks conformed to the losses in their counterparts stateside, while weakness in commodities also contributed to the glum. Elsewhere, KOSPI (-1.6%) pharmaceutical and metal stocks joined the tech underperformance after reports stated South Korea steel exports to US would decline 30% under the new trade agreement and that South Korea will amend its premium pricing program for pharmaceuticals to allow participation of US drug makers. Hang Seng (-1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.1%) were also dragged by the tech slide, while encouraging earnings from big 4 banks ICBC and China Construction Bank only provided brief support and was eventually engulfed by the stock rout.

FTSE

Sky (SKY LN) – Sky Italia are close to a deal with Italy’s Open Fiber to access fast broadband. (Newswires)

GSK (GSK LN) – Nestle (NESN SW), Kraft Heinz (KHC) and Unilever (ULVR LN) are amongst bidders for GlaxoSmithKline’s (GSK LN) Horlicks health union business, which could fetch over USD 4bln. (Newswires)  

GKN (GKN LN)/ Melrose (MRO LN) – An intervention by the UK government has driven Melrose to make a string of commitments  to ensure that the company remains listed and headquartered in the UK, on top of safeguards covering employees, pensioners, suppliers and customers. (The Times)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) – Co. confirmed the sale of its Kestrel Mine to EMR and Adaro for USD 2.25bln. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Capita (CPI LN) – The co. is to set out a five year transformation strategy and rights issue details on April 26th, according to sources. (Newswires)

Entertainment One (ETO LN) – Co. shares were seen higher after Wall Street analysts speculated that the Co. could again become the subject of takeover talk. As a reminder, ITV (ITV LN) made an initial GBP 1bln offer for the company in 2016 but it ditched a deal after talks with eOne broke down over its price. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

BURBERRY (BRBY LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co.’s board are said to lack unanimity over whether CEO Cryan should be replaced or if there are any suitable internal candidates, according to sources. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Ex-Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) chief executive is the rumoured favourite to be the next chairman. (Newswires)

Safran (SAF FP) – Co. announced its plan to start a 2 year share buyback programme for EUR 2.3bln, once the tender offer on Zodiac Aerospace (ZC FP) is completed. (Newswires)

Danone (BN FP) – Co. completed the sale of part of its stake in Yakult (2267 JP) for EUR 1.3bln. As a results, Danone’s stake in Yakult’s outstanding share capital is reduced to 6.61% from 21.29%. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Orpea (ORP FP) – FY revenue +10.5% to EUR 3.138bln. FY EBITDA +15.4% to EUR 548mln. Dividend of EUR 1.10/shr proposed. Co. reiterates its revenue target of EUR 3.40bln for 2018, an 8.3% increase from 2017. Co. also reiterates 2018 target of EBITDA margin equal to or higher than its 2017 level. (Newswires)

Thales (HO FP) – Co. announced it launched its offer on all shares of Gemalto (GTO NA) for EUR 51/shr. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN-EUROPE

Repsol (REP SM) – The co. has won rights to block 5 at Burgos Basin in the Mexican shallow water auction. (Newswires)

Eni (ENI IM) – The CEO of the co. does not see any problems with Russian gas supplies and energy security due to geo-political tensions. Further, the co. did not discover much in the black sea well drilling. (Newswires)

Fincantieri (FCT IM) – FY 2017 net EUR 57mln vs. Prev. EUR 25mln, revenue EUR 5.02bln vs. Prev. EUR 4.43bln and EBITDA EUR 341mln vs. Exp. EUR 320mln. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Co. reported on Tuesday that its statutory auditors have called for a supplement shareholder meeting on April 24th with the action proposed by Elliot to replace six members of the board. Separately, the deputy chairman said that network separation was an assurance for Italian control and ruled out a third mandate. (Newswires)

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

SWATCH (UHR SW) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT BERENBERG

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

* EQUITIES: SPX -1.73% at 2613 , NDX -3.2% at 6530 , DJI -1.43% at 23856

* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): -2.13%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -0.41%, ENERGY (XLE): -1.25%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -2.09%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -1.48%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -1.78%, MATERIALS (XLB): -1.25%, TECH (XLK): -4.13%, TELECOMS (XTL): +0.29%, UTLITIES (XLU): +1.41%.

Equity futures suffered from a risk-off tone on Tuesday as markets await tariff details from the US, while traders are also keeping an eye out for details of Chinese counter-measures. As a result, defensive stocks outperformed with utilities leading, while the SPX and some sectors, such as consumer cyclicals and financials, weighed. Tech was the notable underperformer, closing over 4% lower, led by Nvidia (NVDA) halting its autonomous car tests, and Facebook (FB) due to ongoing privacy investigations. Also, its competitor Twitter (TWTR) slipped after Citron Research turned negative on the stock. Elsewhere, some auto names were firmer after UBS turned positive on the sector. In late trade the 2600 support level held the E-mini, with stocks seeing a small bounce heading into the close.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the losses on Wall St.
content:
• Asian equity markets traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the losses on Wall St.
  • GBP/USD underpinned by reports of a possible imminent plan by the UK for a resolution to the hard border issue
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US GDP, PCE Prices, Pending Home Sales, DoEs and Fed’s Bostic

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the losses on Wall St where trade concerns lingered and tech sold-off, while some also attributed the exacerbated pressure to flows heading into month-end and Easter break. As such, ASX 200 (-0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) were lower as tech stocks conformed to the losses in their counterparts stateside, while weakness in commodities also contributed to the glum. Elsewhere, KOSPI (-1.6%) pharmaceutical and metal stocks joined the tech underperformance after reports stated South Korea steel exports to US would decline 30% under the new trade agreement and that South Korea will amend its premium pricing program for pharmaceuticals to allow participation of US drug makers. Hang Seng (-1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.1%) were also dragged by the tech slide, while encouraging earnings from big 4 banks ICBC and China Construction Bank only provided brief support and was eventually engulfed by the stock rout. Finally, 10yr JGBs saw a tale of two-halves as they initially tracked the gains in T-notes amid a flight to quality from the stock market sell-off and with the BoJ also present in the market under its bond buying program, before gains were then pared on return from the Tokyo break in which prices returned flat.

PBoC skipped open market operations again today for a net drain of CNY 10bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2785 (Prev. 6.2816)


UK/EU

UK is said to inform Irish officials that a resolution to the hard border issue is imminent, according to sources. (Times)


FX

Safe-havens pared back some of the prior day’s gains which helped the greenback’s major counterparts across the pond nurse losses, with EUR/USD regaining lost ground at the 1.2400 handle and with GBP/USD also underpinned by reports of a possible imminent plan by the UK for a resolution to the hard border issue. Furthermore, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses also rebounded from lows despite the risk tone remaining weak, with some support seen alongside confirmation North Korea Leader Kim met with Chinese President Xi in which they exchanged views on improving ties and with the North Korean Leader said to be committed to denuclearization of the Korean peninsula.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued overnight amid the dampened risk appetite with WTI crude futures languishing below the USD 65/bbl with prices also pressured by a surprise build in API crude oil inventories. Elsewhere, gold and copper prices were also lacklustre alongside an uninspiring tone across the complex, and losses in Shanghai commodities trade in which Dalian iron ore futures slipped to its lowest since June shortly after the open and the petro-yuan approached limit down on its 3rd day of trade. 

US API weekly crude stocks (23 Mar) 5.321M vs. Exp. -0.300M (Prev. -2.739M). (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

Reports confirmed that North Korean Leader Kim met with Chinese President Xi in which they exchanged views on improving ties and the situation in Korean peninsula, while North Korea Leader Kim was also said to be committed to denuclearization of Korean peninsula. (Xinhua)

Saudi Foreign Minister said ballistic missiles were launched by Iranian and Hezbollah agents and that Saudi has evidence of Iran arming Houthis with ballistic missiles. Furthermore, the Saudi Foreign Minister stated that the kingdom reserves the right to respond at appropriate time, while there were also separate Saudi Arabia and UN inked agreement to support Yemen. (Newswires)


US

Yields were lower by between 4-6bps across the curve on Tuesday, as risk-off sentiment spurred a Treasury bid. As was the case on Monday, much of the action was focussed in the belly, where yields on 10s breached 2.80% falling to six-week lows. There was flattening in 2s5s, 2s10s, 2s30s by between 5-6bps, though 5s30s widened modestly at settlement. The US Treasury sold $35bln 5-year notes, tailing by 0.3bps – the fifth straight tail at a 5s auction. Cover was slightly higher than recent averages, while higher indirect participation was encouraging. Some remain impressed that the auction performed as it did given the bumper supply this week (slightly short of $300bln including bills). US 10-year T-note futures (m18) settled 14 ticks higher at 120-29.

White House Press Secretary Sanders said yesterday that the US and South Koreans have agreed a trade deal in principle, while reports overnight stated that South Korea steel exports to the US will decline 30% under new trade agreement and that the country will still be subjected to 10% aluminium tariffs, Furthermore, 25% tariffs by the US on pick-ups will be extended for 20yrs and South Korea is to lift caps on US spec. vehicles, while South Korea also agreed to amend premium pricing program for pharmaceuticals to allow participation of US pharmaceutical firms. (Newswires)
